author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Joy of Cooking With a Donabe
description: The Japanese clay vessel is perfect for hot pots like this chicken-meatball nabe.
content: A donabe is a Japanese cooking vessel made of clay — do means “clay,” nabe means “pot.” But if you talk to Naoko Takei Moore, it’s also a way of thinking about cooking, a way of finding joy in the day-to-day of the kitchen. Takei Moore, who was born in Yokohama and grew up in Tokyo, remembers the communal-style donabe at the center of her family’s dining table year round, and how it drew everyone toward it for the simmering dish known as a nabe, or hot pot. “The most common style when I was growing up was yosenabe, which means anything goes,” she said. Some nights, that meant a pot of fish and vegetables in a miso broth, or a clean-out-the-fridge pot of scraps simmered in dashi. Some nights it was tiny handmade meatballs seasoned with white miso and ginger, or big wobbly cuts of soft tofu with whatever vegetables looked good. “I loved it, but didn’t think it was anything special,” she said.

You already know all that,” she told him. “I’m talking about you being such a big nerd!” In Holmon’s room, in the dresser drawers where his clothes should have been, he kept sequentially ordered issues of Daredevil and Green Lantern comics. description: The E.U. is preparing to curb vaccine exports for the next six weeks because of supply shortages.
content: The European Union is preparing to curb vaccine exports for the next six weeks in response to an acute supply shortage — just as a third wave of cases is taxing hospitals and sending country after country into lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Chessin and Brett Marsh
title: A Successful Lifeline for Natomas Students Is Feeling the Strain
description: Wednesday: The Natomas Unified School District has a celebrated mental health program. But the pandemic is taking a toll.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Oregon fights its way past Georgia into the Sweet 16.
description: Oregon fought for its fourth Sweet 16 appearance in program history — in some cases, quite literally.
content: Oregon fought for its fourth Sweet 16 appearance in program history — in some cases, quite literally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Why ‘Cursed’ Olympics Are Pressing Ahead Amid a Pandemic
description: The Games’ organizers say they have a responsibility to hold the event and “build a legacy” for society. But money, national pride and political obduracy are also important drivers.
content: TOKYO — From the moment that Japan pitched to host the 2020 Olympic Games, its organizers have framed it as a symbol of recovery: from a decades-long economic slump, from a devastating earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster and, after a year’s postponement, from a crippling pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Justice Dept. Links Oath Keepers and Proud Boys Ahead of Capitol Riot
description: A member of the Oath Keepers militia said he was communicating with the far-right Proud Boys, prosecutors said, making their first link between the groups.
content: Leaders of the Oath Keepers militia and the far-right group the Proud Boys were in communication in the weeks before the Capitol riot and appear to have coordinated some plans for the day of the attack, prosecutors said in court papers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Argument
title: Is It Time to Cancel Cancel Culture?
description: One of the loudest crusaders against cancel culture squares off against a person said to be one of its victims.
content: Whether it’s Mr. Potato Head, Dr. Seuss or Roseanne, allegations of cancel culture seem to have a regular spot among the trending topics of the internet. Almost every other week, someone’s cancellation becomes the subject of prominent discussion on Twitter, Substack and cable news. Yet its exact meaning is up for debate. What counts as a cancellation? Who gets to decide?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Michael Wilson
title: A Hospital Encounters Vaccine Hesitation Among Its Own Staff
description: At Harlem Hospital, about half of the eligible staff has received a Covid-19 vaccine, reflecting a wariness in the Black community. But it also shows how it is possible to slowly change attitudes about the vaccines.
content: When it was the Rev. Al Sharpton’s turn to get inoculated against Covid-19 last month, he did so on camera at NYC Health + Hospitals/Harlem — a city institution well known for providing health care to the Black community.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: First a Mild Case, Then a Deluge of Misery
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 24, 2021.
content: “I have to wonder: Am I going to recover, or am I going to just figure out how to live with my new brain?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: AstraZeneca stockpile is another chapter in E.U. struggles.
content: Italian authorities found a stockpile of 29 million doses of AstraZeneca’s Covid-19 vaccine languishing in a factory near Rome. The discovery of so many doses raised suspicions that the pharmaceutical company was trying to find a way to export them to Britain or elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Adam Zagajewski, Poet of the Past’s Presence, Dies at 75
description: A dissident in Communist Poland in the late 1960s — his writing was banned for a time — he found wider fame as an exile in Paris and taught in the U.S.
content: Adam Zagajewski, a prizewinning Polish poet and a former dissident in exile whose life and verse reverberated with laments over displacement and reminders that the past perseveres, died on March 21 in Krakow, Poland. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘I Cry on Tuesdays and Fridays’
description: Moms are still primal screaming their hearts out.
content: Michelle Pasos, 46, describes herself as someone who has “always been extremely healthy.” That is until the pandemic, when she ended up in the emergency room because she had a bad reaction to a drug prescribed to bring down her elevated blood pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: This Oscar Race Might Be the Hardest to Predict
description: Though other acting categories appear sewn up, the supporting-actress race is still deliciously chaotic.
content: In a normal Oscar season, you’d be able to pretty much guess the winning actors by now. Think of last year, when the same foursome of Joaquin Phoenix, Renée Zellweger, Brad Pitt and Laura Dern steamrollered their way through every awards show: The only suspense was whether they could sell us on their surprise as their names were called again and again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Tony Murray, Moral Support for a Gay N.B.A. Player, Dies at 60
description: Mr. Murray, along with his husband, helped their nephew Jason Collins become the first player in the league to come out publicly. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Marie Fazio and Manny Fernandez
title: ‘Beyond Comprehension:’ 10 Lives Lost in Boulder
description: Ten people were shot to death at a Colorado grocery store on Monday. The victims included a police officer who was among the first to arrive on the scene.
content: Eric Talley, 51, had already had a career working in the tech industry when he shifted course at age 40 and joined the Boulder Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Mass Shootings and Our Depraved Political Stagnation
description: I want more gun regulation, the kind that scares the gun cult.
content: Another mass shooting. Another round of recriminations. Another push for more gun control. Another pushback from Republicans in Congress doing the bidding of the gun lobby. Another reminder of the unlikelihood of any real federal legislative change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cosimo Bizzarri
title: Finding the Center
description: As he walked the world’s largest labyrinth, the writer Cosimo Bizzarri pondered the concept of getting lost and discovered that it is a common human experience.
content: The narrow, poplar-lined road leading to Labirinto della Masone, the world’s largest labyrinth, runs straight across the flat fields, with only a few mild bends. This is a common sight in the Pianura Padana, the vast plain that takes the Po, Italy’s longest river, from the Alps all the way to the Adriatic Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund White
title: In ‘The Talented Mr. Ripley,’ a Shape-Shifting Protagonist Who’s Up to No Good
description: Patricia Highsmith published the first novel in her series of psychological thrillers in 1955, embedding her own repression, snobbery and sense of chaos into the text.
content: This essay is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation about “The Talented Mr. Ripley,” to be led by Edmund White and held on April 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Peter S. Goodman
title: Suez Canal Blocked After Giant Container Ship Gets Stuck
description: The ship, stretching more than 1,300 feet, ran aground and blocked one of the world’s most vital shipping lanes, leaving more than 100 ships stuck at each end of the canal.
content: CAIRO — Trying to convey the sheer scale of the nearly quarter-mile-long container ship that has been stuck in the Suez Canal since Tuesday evening, some news outlets compared it to the length of four soccer fields. Others simply called it gigantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: How a Stabbing in Israel Echoes Through the Fight Over Online Speech
description: Lawyers, judges and lawmakers are advancing a bold idea: The powerful algorithms used by Facebook, YouTube and Twitter could make them complicit in offline crimes.
content: WASHINGTON — Stuart Force says he found solace on Facebook after his son was stabbed to death in Israel by a member of the militant group Hamas in 2016. He turned to the site to read hundreds of messages offering condolences on his son’s page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adlan Jackson
title: Why Finance Gurus Switched Their Bait From Millions to Thousands of Dollars
description: Their YouTube videos went from promising proprietary secrets for achieving wealth to any little update on the stimulus. And the viewers came rolling in.
content: “Mark your calendar, there’s a big day coming!” On Jan. 9, with the dream of $2,000 stimulus checks not yet deflated, the Southern California real estate broker Kevin Paffrath uploaded a video to his “Meet Kevin” YouTube channel, updating viewers on the status of the stimulus. Sitting before an array of glowing LED screens and pop-culture paraphernalia (a star from the Super Mario games, Thor’s hammer from the Marvel movies), Paffrath, a wiry white man in his late 20s with a close-cropped beard, leaned into the lights and greeted his viewers. Using the earnest eye contact of a veteran YouTuber, he ran through a summary of the situation: the interests at play in Congress, the details of proposed bills, the tangled qualifications for relief. Out of focus, over his shoulder, the monitors reminded us to visit his “Meet Kevin School” and sign up for courses to “Master Stocks”; at the end of the video, we are invited to “#BecomeMore” through investing, to subscribe to his channel and, of course, to smash that “like” button.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: The Most Intimate Portrait Yet of a Black Hole
description: Two years of analyzing the polarized light from a galaxy’s giant black hole has given scientists a glimpse at how quasars might arise.
content: The Event Horizon Telescope collaboration, an international team of radio astronomers that has been staring down the throat of a giant black hole for years, on Wednesday published what it called the most intimate portrait yet of the forces that give rise to quasars, the luminous fountains of energy that can reach across interstellar and intergalactic space and disrupt the growth of distant galaxies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: What Are You Paying for When You Buy a GIF for $25,000?
description: NFTs are the future of the attention economy. Or a scam. Or both.
content: On March 13, Li Jin sold a GIF for $25,000. A link to the moving image, which was assigned a unique bit of code as proof of authenticity and stored on the blockchain, was purchased at auction via the cryptocurrency Ethereum and sold in 24 hours. Depending on whom you ask, the transaction is an example of a thrilling new path for ownership in a digital world that allows creators to sell things directly with no intermediaries, or it’s a total scam. The most bullish argue transactions like Ms. Jin’s could be the beginnings of a brand-new version of the internet, while detractors see it as a reckless, overhyped speculation market and an “ecological nightmare pyramid scheme.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Divorce Rates Are Now Dropping. Here Are Some Reasons Why.
description: Some divorce lawyers and relationship experts said that the uncertainty of the pandemic and financial concerns are two reasons couples are staying together.
content: Divorces from coast to coast have slowed considerably in the last 12 months, according to lawyers, relationship coaches in New York, and records kept by the Superior Court of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As virus cases plateau nationally, Michigan’s rapid surge worries experts.
description: Epidemiologists and infectious disease experts have yet to settle on clear answers to explain the jumps in Michigan.
content: In a sea of heartening news about the U.S. battle against the coronavirus, some experts are casting worried glances at a cloud on the horizon: Michigan, where new cases and hospitalizations are rising with alarming speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: How 10 Prominent Economists Think About Overheating
description: Some notable participants in the debate over the Biden stimulus tell us, in their words, what a too-hot economy would look like.
content: What would it really mean for the economy to overheat? How would we know if the ominous warnings by several prominent economists were coming true?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Sharon Stone Is Telling Her Side of the Story
description: The actress and star of films like “Basic Instinct” and “Casino” writes about her life, upbringing and brushes with death in a new memoir, “The Beauty of Living Twice.”
content: During an extended hospitalization in 2001, when Sharon Stone was being treated for a stroke and a subarachnoid hemorrhage that had bled into her brain, head and spine, she writes that she was visited by her grandmother Lela, who had been dead for 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: In Theaters Now: Movie Houses See Hope in New Covid Relief Package
description: The marquee reads: “see you on the other side.” For Nitehawk Cinema in Brooklyn, the other side may finally be in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: H&M Faces Boycott in China Over Stance on Treatment of Uyghurs
description: The Swedish retailer is the latest fashion business to come under pressure from Chinese consumers after a perceived misstep.
content: The fashion retailer H&M is facing a potential boycott in China after a statement the company made last year expressing deep concerns over reports of forced labor in Xinjiang stirred a social media storm this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Alphonso Davies Wants to Share His Story
description: The Bayern Munich star didn’t learn his own refugee story until his parents talked about it in a team video. He has come to embrace its power, and its effect on others.
content: For a long time, Alphonso Davies knew only the outline of the story. His parents had given him the bare facts, but little more: that they had fled the bloody civil war engulfing their native Liberia; that he had been born in the refugee camp in Ghana where they sought shelter; that they had moved to Canada when he was 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and The New York Times
title: ‘I Will Die Protecting My Country’: In Myanmar, a New Resistance Rises
description: As the nation’s military kills, assaults and terrorizes unarmed civilians each day, some protesters say there is no choice but to fight the army on its own terms.
content: In a jungle in the borderlands of Myanmar, the troops sweated through basic training. They learned how to load a rifle, pull the pin of a hand grenade and assemble a firebomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Indiana gets a balanced performance to beat Belmont.
description: Fourth-seeded Indiana has punched its first-ever ticket to the Sweet 16 with a 70-48 blowout win over No. 12 seed Belmont, keeping the Bruins from an upset run. It is Hoosiers Coach Teri Moren’s first trip to the round of 16.
content: Fourth-seeded Indiana has punched its first-ever ticket to the Sweet 16 with a 70-48 blowout win over No. 12 seed Belmont, keeping the Bruins from an upset run. It is Hoosiers Coach Teri Moren’s first trip to the round of 16.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Mississippi Will Remove ‘Misleading’ Language About Covid-19 Vaccine
description: Bobby Wayne, a retired reverend, called the state seeking help getting the vaccine. He said he was told there was no evidence the vaccine was effective.
content: Bobby Wayne, a retired reverend with prostate cancer and leukemia, had spent a week calling health agencies around his county in Mississippi, trying to find out where to get the Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: In Search of a Vaccine, Some Tourists Find Luck in the Caribbean
description: Roughly 3 percent of vaccines in the U.S. Virgin Islands have gone to tourists, the governor said this week. “Nowhere else in the U.S. can you actually just walk in and get the vaccine,” he said.
content: When Lydia Todman booked a trip to St. Croix with her husband earlier this month, she was hoping only for a relaxing getaway. But when she arrived, she learned she could also get the Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Are You Cleaning Enough? Celebrities Want to Help.
description: Chrissy Teigen, Kris Jenner and Emma Grede have come together to build a saucy cleaning brand.
content: Chrissy Teigen, the appealing multi-hypenate (model-cookbook author-mom, pop-star wife and sassy social media cynosure), and Kris Jenner, the Kardashian-Jenner matriarch presiding over a portfolio of brands with a total value of $2 billion, as Forbes estimated last fall, have some products to sell, and a new company. They’ve been teasing it out on social media for a week, in a mini-movie in which Ms. Teigen plays the fool to Ms. Jenner’s branding dominatrix, with the former mock-pitching the latter on a new product — any product will do — and being whacked in the face for her lousy ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Mitchell
title: Taxpayers Fund Research and Drug Companies Make a Fortune
description: The pharmaceutical industry doesn’t want things to change, but Americans can have both lower prices and innovation.
content: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is worried about how Americans will pay for vaccines in the future. As well she should be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Julie Pomagalski, Former Olympic Snowboarder, Is Killed in an Avalanche
description: The 40-year-old competed for France in the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City and at the Turin Games in 2006.
content: Julie Pomagalski, a two-time Olympian for France in snowboarding and a former world champion, was killed in an avalanche in the Swiss Alps on Tuesday, French sports officials said on Wednesday. She was 40.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Why Your Ballots Are Boring
description: Politicians love to divide and conquer.
content: The Senate is taking up a big bill on voting rights. What do you think the 50 Republican members are going to do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: 14 Arrested at Protest Over U.K. Policing Bill
description: The rally in Bristol followed violent clashes on Sunday. The demonstrations are part of a broader movement against a proposed law that would bolster the authorities’ power to disperse protests.
content: LONDON — Fourteen protesters have been arrested in Bristol, in southwestern England, at a rally to denounce a policing bill that would enact restrictions on peaceful demonstrations. The rally, part of a wider movement against the proposed legislation, came after clashes in the city on Sunday that left officers wounded and drew condemnation from officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Dupré, Michael Gold, Allyson Waller and Madeleine Ngo
title: More than 40 states say they will meet or beat Biden’s May 1 deadline for vaccine eligibility for all adults.
description: On Wednesday, Louisiana moved up the date for expanded eligibility to Monday, while Idaho changed it to April 5.
content: The push to get Americans vaccinated has picked up momentum in recent days. Governors and public health officials in more than 40 states have said they will meet or beat President Biden’s goal of making every adult eligible for a vaccine by May 1, and at least 30 states plan to start universal eligibility in March or April.
source.name: The New York Times

title: With a Police Raid and the Threat of Export Curbs on Vaccines, the E.U. Plays Tough
description: The bloc is tightening export rules in a bid to speed up its disappointing Covid inoculation campaign and stem political criticism.
content: BRUSSELS — Tipped off by European authorities, a team of Italian police inspectors descended on a vaccine-manufacturing facility outside Rome over the weekend. They discovered 29 million doses of AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines, feeding suspicions that the company was trying to spirit them overseas instead of distributing them in the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihee Kim-Kort
title: I’m a Scholar of Religion. Here’s What I See in the Atlanta Shootings.
description: Did racism or theology or gender motivate the shootings in Georgia? All of the above.
content: When news about the Atlanta killings broke, I saw in Korean sources first that six of the dead were Asian women, four of Korean descent. I didn’t yet know their names; I mourned them as Daughter, Big Sister, Mother, Aunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Ingemi
title: Louisville gets another comeback to beat Northwestern.
description: Following an abysmal first half, No. 2 seed Louisville flexed its starting rotation and stormed back for a 62-53 win over No. 7 seed Northwestern to earn a berth in the Sweet 16. The Cardinals outscored the Wildcats 55-28 in the second half.

title: What Does It Mean to Be a Living Thing?
description: In “Life’s Edge,” Carl Zimmer examines the many scientific attempts to define what it is that exactly constitutes life.
content: LIFE’S EDGEThe Search for What It Means to Be AliveBy Carl Zimmer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Her Film on Sex Assault Depicts Her Own and Fuels a #MeToo Moment
description: Danijela Stajnfeld included her account of being assaulted in a film that has led to contentious debate in Serbia and prompted other women to come forward to say they were sexually abused.
content: Her face graced billboards in Belgrade. She appeared regularly in Serbian movies, magazines and television shows. Trained at the prestigious Faculty of Dramatic Arts in Belgrade, Danijela Stajnfeld had, by the age of 26 in 2011, won two major theater prizes and was a permanent member with the esteemed Belgrade Drama Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Chevlen
title: So You Want to Have a Lucid Dream?
description: The internet is home to all kinds of advice about how to experience consciousness while dreaming. What works?
content: Questions about the phenomenon of lucid dreaming — that is, experiencing consciousness while in a dream state — have been tossed around for thousands of years. Aristotle wrote about lucid dreams in 350 B.C.E., and Buddhists have practiced “dream yoga” for centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Blinken’s Welcome by NATO Doesn’t Hide Differences on Key Issues
description: President Biden’s top diplomat sought to soothe allies battered by former President Donald J. Trump, promising coordination and consultation. But underlying problems remain.
content: BRUSSELS —  Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to smooth alliance feathers ruffled by the previous U.S. administration on a trip to NATO and the European Union this week, but his diplomatic calm did not completely mask deep-seated issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Five Tech Commandments to a Safer Digital Life
description: We can survive a world of ever-changing tech if we remember these principles.
content: Tech is always changing, and so is the way we use it. That means we are always finding new ways to let our guard down for bad actors to snoop on our data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Clueless About Discord? Read This.
description: Two avid readers from South Africa show what they find special about this talking and texting app.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: N.F.L. Clears Way for End to Washington Football Team Turmoil
description: The league is expected to approve a measure that will allow Daniel Snyder to buy total control of the team.
content: Seeking to move past a year of tumult over the team’s former name and a sexual harassment investigation of its front office, the owner of the Washington Football Team is close to a deal with fellow N.F.L. owners that will give him greater control over the franchise while he pays a fine for executives’ misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu’s Party Leads but Faces Obstacles to Forming Government in Israel
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s party took a lead in Israel’s fourth election in two years, but updated exit polls projected a stalemate that could extend Israel’s political deadlock.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s party held a lead in Israel’s fourth election in two years, exit polls projected Wednesday, but neither his right-wing alliance nor a diverse bloc of opposition parties had a clear path to a majority coalition, creating a stalemate that could extend Israel’s political deadlock for weeks if not months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Rachel Levine, Biden’s pick for health post, is first openly transgender official to be confirmed by Senate.
description: The Senate vote, 52 to 48, followed a contentious confirmation hearing that became a flash point in the battle over transgender rights.
content: Dr. Rachel Levine, President Biden’s pick to be assistant secretary for health, made history on Wednesday by becoming the first openly transgender person confirmed by the Senate to a federal position, and immediately vowed to “promote policies that advance the health and well-being of all Americans” and to fight for transgender youth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Bad News Bias
description: The U.S. media is offering a different picture of Covid-19 from science journals or the international media, a study finds.
content: Bruce Sacerdote, an economics professor at Dartmouth College, noticed something last year about the Covid-19 television coverage that he was watching on CNN and PBS. It almost always seemed negative, regardless of what was he seeing in the data or hearing from scientists he knew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Sarah Kessler
title: Will This Boom Go Bust?
description: The bull market is one year old. Can it last?
content: The bull market is now a year old, with the S&P 500 up nearly 75 percent from its low point at this time last year. That recovery, The Times’s Matt Phillips writes, is “a testament to the unbridled enthusiasm that let investors shrug off the economic carnage of the pandemic and buy stocks — and pretty much anything else.” The factors that have stoked the rally also raise questions about whether it can last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Two Lonely Generations Are Helping Each Other Heal’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how young adults and older people have suffered most from loneliness during the pandemic and how interaction between them might be the best medicine for each.
content: Featured Article: “How Two Lonely Generations Are Helping Each Other Heal” by Richard Schiffman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll, Michael Forsythe, Frances Robles and Linda Qiu
title: 2 Immigrant Paths: One Led to Wealth, the Other Ended in Death in Atlanta
description: Owners and employees at the spas attacked last week were immigrants with similar dreams, but were separated by a vast gap in money and power.
content: Sue-ling Wang prided himself on being a self-made businessman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Task: Overhaul the Economy, as Fast as Possible
description: The president will need to make rapid, strategic choices to advance his “Build Back Better” agenda, possibly including dropping some campaign plans to salvage the rest.
content: WASHINGTON — After a two-month, $2 trillion sprint to pass aid for an economy still hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic, President Biden is finally set to detail his “Build Back Better” agenda next week in Pittsburgh. Its name, carried over from the 2020 campaign, has become a catchall phrase that cabinet officials and junior aides use to describe all manner of plans to overhaul American capitalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: M.L.B. Will Analyze Spin Rate to Detect Ball Doctoring
description: In a continuing effort to combat the use of foreign substances to increase ball movement, baseball will incorporate Statcast data.
content: Doctoring baseballs with foreign substances to increase spin and movement has been around for as long as baseball has been played. To try to combat the practice, Major League Baseball is going high tech for the 2021 season, adding spin rate analysis to its arsenal of methods for detecting changes and enforcing existing policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Jesus Jiménez
title: Free With Your Covid Shot: Beer, Arcade Tokens and Krispy Kreme Doughnuts
description: Businesses across the United States and beyond are offering free stuff to people who have been vaccinated. The perks include movie popcorn, alcohol and even marijuana.
content: The benefits of getting vaccinated against Covid-19 — namely, protection against a dangerous virus — should be obvious by this stage in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: George Segal, Veteran of Drama and TV Comedy, Is Dead at 87
description: He is best remembered for his Oscar-nominated dramatic role in “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and was later a familiar comic actor.
content: George Segal, whose long career began in serious drama but who became one of America’s most reliable and familiar comic actors, first in the movies and later on television, died on Tuesday in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Daniel Wolf, 65, Dies; Helped Create a Market for Art Photography
description: In 1984, he quietly amassed 25,000 photos for the J. Paul Getty Museum, jump-starting collectors’ interest in the medium.
content: Daniel Wolf pulled off what may have been the greatest legal art caper of all time: Over the course of two years in the early 1980s, he quietly amassed some 25,000 classic and contemporary photographs, buying them from the world’s most renowned collectors on behalf of his client the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Xiaowei Wang
title: What Is Amazon Doing to Our Country?
description: In “Fulfillment,” Alec MacGillis tours America to understand how one company’s culture and capitalistic impulses are seeping into our way of life.
content: FULFILLMENTWinning and Losing in One-Click AmericaBy Alec MacGillis
source.name: The New York Times
